nutrientReferenceData.description: Calories required to maintain health and support daily activities.
nutrientReferenceData.benefits: Provides energy for metabolic processes, physical activity, and growth.
nutrientReferenceData.excessEffects: Weight gain, obesity, increased risk of metabolic diseases.
nutrientReferenceData.source: FAO/WHO Human Energy Requirements – adapted to West African populations

nutrientReferenceData.description: Macronutrient essential for muscle repair, enzyme production, and immune function.
nutrientReferenceData.benefits: Supports growth, tissue repair, immune health.
nutrientReferenceData.deficiencyEffects: Muscle wasting, weakened immunity, delayed wound healing.
nutrientReferenceData.excessEffects: Possible kidney strain in susceptible individuals.
nutrientReferenceData.source: WHO Protein and Amino Acid Requirements – Ghana food context

nutrientReferenceData.description: Fat-soluble vitamin important for vision, immune function, and skin health.
nutrientReferenceData.excessEffects: Toxicity symptoms like headaches, liver damage.
nutrientReferenceData.source: WHO/FAO Vitamin A guidelines for sub-Saharan Africa

nutrientReferenceData.description: Mineral vital for oxygen transport and energy metabolism.
Electrolyte that regulates fluid balance and nerve function.
nutrientReferenceData.benefits: Maintains fluid balance, supports muscle and nerve function.
nutrientReferenceData.deficiencyEffects: Rare – may cause hyponatremia symptoms like confusion, seizures.
nutrientReferenceData.excessEffects: High blood pressure, increased heart disease risk.
nutrientReferenceData.source: WHO Sodium Intake Guidelines for Adults

nutrientReferenceData.description: Water-soluble vitamin important for immune function, antioxidant defense, and collagen synthesis.
nutrientReferenceData.benefits: Boosts immunity, improves iron absorption from plant-based meals like waakye and red-red.
nutrientReferenceData.source: WHO Vitamin C Requirements – Adapted for West Africa

nutrientReferenceData.description: Macronutrient essential for energy storage, hormone production, and absorption of fat-soluble vitamins (A, D, E, K).
nutrientReferenceData.benefits: Provides concentrated energy, supports cell structure, aids absorption of vitamins.
nutrientReferenceData.deficiencyEffects: Dry skin, poor vitamin absorption, hormonal imbalance.
nutrientReferenceData.excessEffects: Weight gain, increased risk of heart disease (especially from saturated and trans fats).
nutrientReferenceData.source: WHO/FAO Dietary Fats Guidelines – Adapted for West African populations

nutrientReferenceData.description: Primary source of energy for the body, especially the brain and muscles during activity.
nutrientReferenceData.benefits: Supports brain function, provides fuel for daily activities, spares protein for tissue repair.
nutrientReferenceData.deficiencyEffects: Low energy, mental fatigue, muscle breakdown.
nutrientReferenceData.excessEffects: Weight gain, increased risk of metabolic diseases when from refined sources.
nutrientReferenceData.source: WHO/FAO Carbohydrate Requirements – Adapted for West Africa

nutrientReferenceData.description: Indigestible part of plant foods that aids digestion and supports gut health.
nutrientReferenceData.benefits: Promotes healthy digestion, lowers cholesterol, helps control blood sugar.
nutrientReferenceData.deficiencyEffects: Constipation, higher risk of heart disease and type 2 diabetes.
nutrientReferenceData.source: WHO Fiber Intake Recommendations – Adapted for African diets

nutrientReferenceData.description: Simple carbohydrate that provides quick energy but lacks essential nutrients.
nutrientReferenceData.benefits: Quick energy source, enhances taste of foods.
nutrientReferenceData.deficiencyEffects: No direct deficiency effects; body can produce glucose from other sources.
nutrientReferenceData.excessEffects: Tooth decay, weight gain, increased risk of diabetes and heart disease.

nutrientReferenceData.description: Mineral essential for bone health, muscle function, and nerve signaling.
nutrientReferenceData.benefits: Builds strong bones and teeth, supports muscle contraction and nerve transmission.
nutrientReferenceData.excessEffects: Kidney stones, impaired absorption of other minerals.
nutrientReferenceData.source: WHO/FAO Calcium Requirements – Adapted for African diets

nutrientReferenceData.description: Electrolyte that helps regulate fluid balance, muscle contractions, and nerve signals.
nutrientReferenceData.benefits: Supports heart health, lowers blood pressure, aids muscle function.
nutrientReferenceData.excessEffects: Hyperkalemia (especially in kidney disease), which can cause heart problems.
nutrientReferenceData.source: WHO Potassium Intake Guidelines – Adapted for West Africa
